''THE next song, 'Scratch,' requires four alligator clips, a bolt, a comb and a guitar slide to make it sound just right,'' Roger Miller said Wednesday night at CBGB. He calmly placed those objects on the strings of a Yamaha electric grand piano and -using reverberation and distortion devices, a synthesizer and a tape-loop echo-repeat system - played another plinking, clanking, crunching, howling song.

In solo performances he calls ''maximum electric piano,'' Mr. Miller deploys keyboards to create the kind of driving, half-cacophonous rock he used to play with the band Mission of Burma. He layers on chords, percussive riffs - part Stravinsky, part minimalism - and noises, sometimes singing erudite lyrics (like ''No Man Is Hurting Me,'' based on the Odyssey) or playing a fuzz-toned synthesizer solo amid the rhythmic clatter. His songs tend to move from one sonic assemblage to another in carefully paced waves of harmony and noise.

Mr. Miller's model is clearly Jimi Hendrix, to whom he paid tribute with a version of Hendrix's ''Manic Depression.'' He wants to do for the electric piano what Hendrix did for guitar, creating a new vocabulary of electronic noises. Some of those noises are now familiar - with enough distortion, an electric piano sounds a lot like an electric guitar -but Mr. Miller's songs have jolts in all the right places.

Mr. Miller also has a sense of humor. Although he is not related to the Roger Miller who wrote ''Big River,'' he encored with a version of the other Mr. Miller's ''King of the Road,'' a song about trailers, that sounded like vans in collision.
